Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
You will find enclosed graphs showing yellow fever cases
and deaths reported in Mexico which were used in the docket for the
meeting of the International Health Board on May 22, 1923. I am
sending you also maps showing yellow fever areas in the Western Hemis-
phere and the location of the yellow fever epidemic in Colombia.

We have sent you from time to time information concerning
yellow fever conditions in Africa, Brazil, and Colombia. To make
sure that you have as up-to-date information as is available from
the reports that have come to us, I am sending the following summary:

COLOMBIA. Reports were received in March of the outbreak of an
epidemic in Bucaramanga, Colombia. There had been 20 cases with
8 deaths from a disease having many of the symptoms of yellow
fever. Later investigations showed that the disease first ap-
peared as a single case in November, 1922, with 2 more cases in
December; from January 1 to March 7 there appeared 70 more cases
with 20 deaths. Diagnosis of yellow fever was at first ruled
out because of the high altitude and the distance of Bucaramanga
from any infected area. On invitation of government, the Board
sent Dr. J. H. White, Dr. W. Pareja of Guayaquil, and Dr. O. L.
Pothier of New Orleans to investigate the situation.

Dr. Pareja and Dr. Pothier joined Dr. White in Colon on
April 18. They went at once to Bucaramanga by way of Barranquilla.
Doctor Carter
June 1, 1923
2
Under date of May 4, a cable was received from Dr. Miller confirm-
ing the diagnosis of yellow fever in Bucaramanga. A cable dated
May 16 was later received, saying: diagnosis accepted by government;
further investigation necessary; Cucuta regarded as one possible
source, Barranquilla another; investigation will require about six
weeks longer; government agrees to assume one-half of the expense;
probable cost to the Board of undertaking control measures in Col-
ombia from June, 1923, to January, 1924, $50,000.

VENEZUELA. Through the New York office of the Asiatic Petroleum Com-
pany, Limited, with which the Colon Development Company is affili-
ated, we hear of a rumor of a yellow fever epidemic in the vicinity
of Mene Grande, an oil centre near Lagunillas, in 1921. The infor-
mation was only hearsay. Effort is being made to trace the rumor.

BRAZIL. The federal government has authorized the Department of Public
Health of Brazil to accept the co-operation of the Board in yellow
fever work. It is expected that a representative will go to Brazil
as soon as possible to co-operate with the Brazilian authorities in
making a survey of yellow fever conditions, particularly in Bahia
and Ceara.

WEST AFRICA. An epidemic of yellow fever was reported from Grand Bassam,
Ivory Coast, in August, 1922. Twenty cases with 3 deaths were re-
ported, together with one death in Togoland. There have been rumors
of sporadic cases in Nigeria, Dahomey, Gold Coast, Gambia, and French
Soudan.

Autopsy specimens have been received from only one case
from West Africa suspected of being yellow fever. The specimens
were examined by Doctor Darling and Doctor Noguchi. Doctor Darl-
ing reported that he found none of the characteristic lesions of
yellow fever, but the pigmentation and the bile staining of malaria.
Doctor Noguchi considers it a borderline case which with the type
of degeneration and necrosis in the liver, might have been either
infectious jaundice or yellow fever. The clinical record he thinks
would indicate either yellow fever or a very severe case of infec-
tious jaundice. The histological appearance of the organs would
indicate infectious jaundice rather than yellow fever. Efforts
which have been made to obtain further autopsy tissues have so far
been unsuccessful.

A cable just received from Doctor White dated Colon,
May 30, 1923, states that he is expected to sail on the Parismina
on May thirty first. This should bring him to New Orleans about
June eighth.
